task.title: Adding Apache Class to Example Group
task.shortdesc: In this procedure, you'll add the apache class to the apache_example group you created in the previous task.

step.cmd: In the Class name field, begin typing "apache," and select it from the autocomplete list.
Click Add class and then click Commit 1 change.
step.stepresult: The apache class now appears in the list of classes for your agent node. You can see this list by clicking Nodes and then clicking your node in the Nodes list. A page opens with your node's details.

step.cmd: From your agent node, navigate to /var/www/html, and create a file named index.html.
Open index.html with the text editor of your choice and fill it with some content (e.g., "Hello World").
From the console, navigate to the Live Management page, and select the Control Puppet.
Click runonce and then Run. This will configure the node using the newly-assigned class. Wait one or two minutes.
Open a browser and enter the IP address for the agent node, adding port 80 on the end (e.g., www.myagentnodeIP:80).
You will see the contents of /var/www/html/index.html displayed.

taskbody.result: Result: Puppet Enterprise is now managing the default Apache vhost on your agent node. At this point, you can check out the Apache "ReadMe" on the Forge to explore options for managing your Apache instances as needed. The *Nix module writing QSG (./quick_writing_nix.html) discusses how to write your own class that manages a web app running on an Apache virtual host.
